context: The temperature of the experimental set-up was maintained at 30(±3)°C using a thermoregulated chamber. Experiments were performed in triplicate. The wire-mesh boxes containing the solid support were inoculated with 30 mL of a MSM suspension of active mycelium (fungal biomass) at an initial concentration of 0.35 gbiomass L−1 (equivalent to 3.28 mgbiomass g−1 dry vermiculite). The reactors were supplied with 30 g m−3 of n-pentane in the air headspace as the only carbon and energy source and were operated batch wise for 30 days. The fungal inoculum was previously grown for three weeks at 30 °C in MSM containing potato dextrose agar (2.0 g L−1) and glycerol (1.0 g L−1) (Vergara-Fernández et al., 2011a). Continuous n-pentane feeding under sterile conditions was initiated when fungal growth achieved the stationary phase by day 30, which was inferred by the negligible CO2 production and the presence of a high aerial biomass density. Before the onset of n-pentane feeding, 5 mL of MSM was supplemented in order to maintain the microbial activity while limiting the growth of biomass.
